note.body:
I added the `contributing` link. I am not convinced about the `provides` and `replaces` to be honest, it feels wrong to add the desktop file there if you already define it in 
```xml
  <launchable type="desktop-id">ca.desrt.dconf-editor.desktop</launchable>
```

note.body: At least when in a sandbox, gsettings are file backed. I am not sure if this is the case, but doing io a few hundred times when the user resizes the window sounds like a bad idea. I think it is just simpler to save the size on exit.

target_title: Draft: Update from gtk3 to gtk4

note.body: Oh thanks! Glad I can remove all those.

target_title: Draft: Update from gtk3 to gtk4

note.body: I noticed https://developer.gnome.org/documentation/tutorials/save-state.html suggests just binding your window size directly to GSettings, which is super easy but also feels slightly alarming since we don't have any flags that say "please don't spam dbus with hundreds of property changes when the user drags the window, it isn't that important" ... but maybe that gets sorted out on its own?

target_title: Draft: Update from gtk3 to gtk4

note.body: Yeah, my goal is to delete all these Adaptive-whatever widgets in a final step here. I think the bookmark view is the last consumer still floating around, so once that's all finished I can just go through and drop all the unused classes. Good advice, though! I ended up using _effectively_ Baobab's pathbar, but it could do with some little modernizations like that as well :)

note.body:
You do this for saving the window size with those value. I don't know when the app saves it's size, but nowadays most apps load the size when the window is being constructed and save it on e.g. close_request.

Note that one also has to save/load whether the app is maximized.

target_title: Draft: Update from gtk3 to gtk4

note.body:
I ended up jumping ahead with the delay mode redesign because I broke the popover stuff anyway and it didn't seem to be worth keeping it. Ended up with a similar scheme to the current master branch, but I'm using `AdwBottomSheet`, like this (don't mind the graphics glitches):

![Screenshot_From_2024-11-22_14-44-24](/uploads/942ab060ab5e8c7e462ec5e6e1497df6/Screenshot_From_2024-11-22_14-44-24.png)

![Screenshot_From_2024-11-22_14-43-10](/uploads/3f49f224a05ba5d1e99bd5e142b650ea/Screenshot_From_2024-11-22_14-43-10.png)

It feels good to me - the keyboard navigation is even slightly improved since a bottom sheet is less intent on closing itself than a popover - although I'll confess, I didn't take the time to consult the HIG for this. Suggestions are welcome :)

target_title: Don’t split strings

note.body: Can you please look into this?

target_title: Inconsistent capitalization

note.body: The renaming didn’t happen in 5 years. Can you please just decide on a capitalization and implement it? Now would be a good time to make the change, as we’re early in the cycle and it gives translators plenty of time to update their translations.

target_title: Modernize the AppStream metadata
Ability to clean dconf database (remove keys not defined by schemas)
Polish: Go into pathbar edit mode after clicking in it

note.body: This is a task I have for myself under !44. There's a feature request for libadwaita to add a common pathbar widget, which would be really useful here since dconf-editor's is super old and it's a bit silly having to keep building this kind of widget from scratch: GNOME/libadwaita#325. In a pinch, Baobab has a nice and simple pathbar implementation we could borrow: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/baobab/-/blob/main/src/baobab-pathbar.vala.
